  • ID required: You must show identification matching the name on your ticket
  • Physical demands: Wear comfortable, lightweight clothing and appropriate shoes. Not suitable for those with claustrophobia or significant mobility limitations
  • Entrance location: Porta della Mandorla on the north side of the cathedral, not the main doors
  • Baggage deposit mandatory: All bags must be left at the free deposit before entering
  • Strict time windows: Your ticket is valid for a specific 45-minute entry window. Late arrivals forfeit entry

Alternatives within the Duomo complex: Giotto's Campanile (Bell Tower) offers alternative panoramic views with a different perspective of the Dome itself (414 steps). The Baptistery is famous for Ghiberti's bronze "Gates of Paradise" and stunning gold mosaic ceiling. Cathedral floor entry is free (modest dress required). Your combined Duomo Pass (€30) includes all these plus the Duomo Museum.

sections.title: Day One: Afternoon & Evening
sections.content:
Lunch: Mercato Centrale (1:00pm–2:00pm)

The Mercato Centrale provides an ideal lunch location. The ground floor features vendors selling fresh produce and local specialties — this is where Florentines actually shop. The upstairs food hall offers diverse options: fresh pasta, schiacciata (Florentine flatbread), pizza, bistecca alla fiorentina, and more. You'll also find local products perfect for gifts: wine, olive oil, honey, truffle products, and other regional specialties.

Uffizi Gallery (2:00pm–5:30pm)

Dedicate your afternoon to the Uffizi Gallery, home to masterpieces by Botticelli (Birth of Venus), Leonardo da Vinci (Annunciation), Michelangelo (Doni Tondo), Caravaggio, and dozens of other Renaissance masters.

Essential preparation:

  • Walk-up entry typically means hours-long waits or no admission — advance timed tickets are essential
  • Arrive at least 20–30 minutes before your scheduled entry for security lines
  • Oversized water bottles (over 500ml), glass bottles, other drinks, and all food are prohibited. Large bags require cloakroom storage
  • If booking through third parties, verify whether your confirmation is an actual entry ticket or a voucher requiring exchange
  • The Uffizi is vast — study a floor plan beforehand to identify must-see works

Don't miss: Windows overlooking the Arno River and Ponte Vecchio — unique perspectives. Allocate 2–3 hours minimum.

Evening: Aperitivo & Dinner in Oltrarno (6:00pm onwards)

Experience the Florentine tradition of aperitivo. Consider rooftop locations in the Oltrarno district for exceptional views without premium pricing. Then explore the Oltrarno neighborhood for dinner — known for authentic trattorias and artisan workshops offering genuine Florentine atmosphere. This is where you'll find restaurants serving locals rather than primarily tourists. Be sure to try bistecca alla fiorentina if you haven't already — the massive T-bone steak, served rare, is a Tuscan tradition best experienced at traditional trattorias.

sections.title: Day Two: Morning
sections.content:
Palazzo Pitti (9:00am–11:00am)

Visit Palazzo Pitti, one of Florence's largest architectural monuments. The former Medici grand ducal palace houses multiple museums:

  • Palatine Gallery: Renaissance and Baroque masterpieces by Raphael, Titian, Rubens, displayed in opulent rooms
  • Gallery of Modern Art: Italian art from the 18th–20th centuries
  • Museum of Costume and Fashion: Historic fashion and textiles
  • Silver Museum: Medici treasures and decorative arts

Choose which museums interest you most, or focus on the Palatine Gallery if time is limited — it's the most impressive collection.

Boboli Gardens (11:00am–12:30pm)

Behind Palazzo Pitti extend the Boboli Gardens, a vast 16th-century landscape of manicured avenues, fountains, grottoes, and sculptures. This is Italian garden design emphasizing grand perspectives and controlled nature.

Practical considerations:

  • Allow at least 90 minutes to explore properly
  • Wear comfortable shoes; paths are gravel and there are hills
  • Bring water, especially in summer when shade is limited
  • Spring (April–May) and autumn offer the most comfortable temperatures

Don't miss Buontalenti's fantastical grotto near the entrance — strange, theatrical, quintessentially Renaissance. Combined tickets (approximately €16) cover both Palazzo Pitti museums and Boboli Gardens.

sections.title: Day Two: Afternoon & Evening
sections.content:
Lunch in Oltrarno (1:00pm–2:00pm)

Find a trattoria in the Oltrarno district for a leisurely lunch. The streets around Santo Spirito and San Frediano offer numerous choices — see the dining chapter of this guide for recommendations.

Wine Windows & Street Discoveries (2:00pm–3:30pm)

Embark on a delightful stroll discovering Florence's unique "wine windows" (buchette del vino). These historical hatches, once used to sell wine directly to passersby during plague times, are scattered throughout Florence. Look for small, arched openings at approximately waist height on older building facades. Concentrations can be found in the Santo Spirito neighborhood, along Borgo degli Albizi, and on Via delle Belle Donne.

Mercato Nuovo, Ponte Vecchio & Medici Chapels (3:30pm–5:30pm)

Make your way to Mercato Nuovo (Porcellino Market) — try authentic lampredotto from market vendors and rub the bronze boar's nose for good luck. Cross Ponte Vecchio, Florence's famous medieval bridge lined with jewelry shops — the only Florentine bridge the Germans spared during World War II.

Continue to the Medici Chapels for opulent family mausoleums featuring Michelangelo's sculptures (Dawn, Dusk, Night, Day) in the New Sacristy and the astonishingly ornate Chapel of the Princes. Entry approximately €9, open daily 8:15am–1:50pm.

Alternative afternoon options: Bargello Museum (exceptional sculpture collection) or Museo di San Marco (Fra Angelico's remarkable frescoes in monks' cells).

Piazzale Michelangelo for Sunset (6:00pm onwards)

Head to Piazzale Michelangelo for spectacular panoramic views, particularly stunning at sunset. Walk up (15–20 minutes, steep) or take buses 12 or 13. Arrive about an hour before sunset to secure a good viewing spot.

Enjoy dinner in the San Niccolò neighborhood below, known for lively atmosphere and authentic options away from tourist-heavy zones.

Gelato Tips

Seek out gelaterias known for quality ingredients rather than towering, artificially colored displays. Look for natural colors (pale green pistachio, not neon), ingredients listed prominently, and gelato stored in covered metal containers rather than piled high in display cases.

sections.title: Final Thoughts
sections.content:
This itinerary is comprehensive but adjust based on your pace and interests. It's better to truly experience fewer things than to rush through everything.

Two days provides a solid introduction to Florence's essential experiences and begins to reveal the city's character. You'll see world-famous masterpieces, taste Florentine cuisine, and explore beyond the immediate tourist radius.

However, 48 hours also means you'll leave wanting more — which is perhaps the best outcome. Florence rewards extended visits and repeat trips. If this is your first visit, use these two days to identify what you'd explore more deeply next time: Renaissance art, Medici history, Tuscan cuisine, artisan crafts, or simply the pleasure of sitting in piazzas watching Florentine life unfold.

If you have additional days, Florence serves as an excellent base for Tuscany day trips. San Gimignano, Siena, Chianti wine region, and Tuscan hill towns are all accessible — see the Day Trips chapter for detailed information.

Approach these 48 hours with realistic expectations: you'll experience highlights and get a genuine sense of the city, but you won't see everything. Florence has been accumulating stories for centuries, and two days barely scratches the surface. But it's an excellent beginning.
